H0.text: The nucleus is the least dense region of an atom explains why a positively‑charged hydrogen ion has a much smaller radius than a neutral hydrogen atom.

H1.text: Electrons are located far from the nuclei of their atoms, which explains why a positively‑charged hydrogen ion has a much smaller radius than a neutral hydrogen atom.

H2.text: Most of the volume of atoms is filled with the particles they contain explains why a positively‑charged hydrogen ion has a much smaller radius than a neutral hydrogen atom.

H3.text: The repulsion of protons and neutrons keeps them on opposite ends of atoms, which best explains why a positively‑charged hydrogen ion has a much smaller radius than a neutral hydrogen atom.

A4.text: The resulting ion, which consists solely of a proton for the usual isotope, is written as 'H+'.
